note: Core weapons only. For buoyancy, gas cell vulnerability, aerial boarding, and altitude weather rules, see the full Sails & Gasbags supplement.

vehicles.name: Sky Skiff
vehicles.desc: A small open-decked vessel held aloft by a single levitation crystal, crewed by two and armed with whatever the crew brought aboard. She's the rowboat of the sky — fast, fragile, and the first thing you grab when you need to be somewhere above the clouds in a hurry.
vehicles.notes: The sky skiff is your starter aerial vehicle. She teaches sky combat basics without overwhelming new players. Two crew — pilot and gunner — and no margin for error. One hit and she's falling. Perfect for courier missions, scouting, and dramatic escapes from tower windows.

vehicles.name: Cloud Cutter
vehicles.desc: A sleek single-masted vessel with enchanted sails that catch winds no mundane canvas could hold. She's fast, she's agile, and her narrow beam lets her thread through canyon gaps and fortress arrowslits that larger skyships can't reach.
vehicles.notes: The cloud cutter is your speed vessel. She outruns everything heavier and outmanoeuvres everything the same size. Use her for chases through mountain passes, between floating islands, and through the rigging of larger skyships. Her agility is her survival.

vehicles.name: Sky Brig
vehicles.desc: Two masts, a respectable broadside, and enough deck space for a crew of forty. She's the workhorse of any skyfleet — fast enough to patrol, tough enough to fight pirates, and common enough that nobody looks twice when she docks at a floating port.
vehicles.notes: The sky brig is your campaign vessel. She's the right size for a player party to crew meaningfully, armed enough for combat encounters, and versatile enough for any mission. Build your sky-sailing campaign around her and everything scales naturally.

vehicles.name: War Galleon (Sky)
vehicles.desc: Three masts, two gun decks, and a hull reinforced with ironwood planking. She's the line-of-battle ship of the sky, carrying enough broadside weight to reduce lesser vessels to falling wreckage. Her crew of two hundred fight with the discipline of a naval tradition centuries old.
vehicles.notes: The war galleon is your set-piece battle ship. She appears in fleet actions, royal escorts, and siege breaking. If the players are aboard, they're in a major engagement. If she's the enemy, they need a plan that doesn't involve trading broadsides.

vehicles.name: Dwarven Ironclad (Sky)
vehicles.desc: Iron hull, steam engines, and the bloody-minded engineering philosophy of a race that considers 'over-built' a compliment. She's slow, she's heavy, and she shrugs off attacks that would splinter a wooden vessel. Dwarven gunners don't aim — they let the enemy come to them.
vehicles.notes: The ironclad is your damage sponge. She can't be outfought but she can be outrun. Her steam engines make her wind-independent, which is a massive tactical advantage when the wind dies or shifts. Use her as the immovable anchor of a fleet or the unstoppable threat that conventional skyships can't hurt.

vehicles.name: Observation Balloon
vehicles.desc: A silk envelope, a wicker basket, and a crew of two who hang above the battlefield reporting enemy movements to the forces below. She goes up, she stays up, and she sees everything within twenty miles. She cannot run, she cannot fight, and she prays the enemy has no archers.
vehicles.notes: The observation balloon is your aerial scout for ground campaigns. She provides the commander with a bird's-eye view of the battlefield. She's defenceless — protecting her from sky-borne threats is someone else's job. If she's shot down, the ground force fights blind.

vehicles.name: Transport Barge (Sky)
vehicles.desc: Wide, flat-bottomed, and enchanted for lift rather than speed. She carries cargo, troops, and siege equipment between floating cities and surface kingdoms. She's the freight vessel that makes sky-commerce possible, and she moves with all the urgency of a loaded ox-cart.
vehicles.notes: The sky barge is your escort mission and your prize. She carries something valuable — troops, supplies, treasure, refugees — and she can't protect herself. The players escort her through hostile airspace, and every encounter is a rearguard action while she lumbers onward.

vehicles.name: Elven Windrunner
vehicles.desc: Grown rather than built, her hull is living wood shaped by centuries of patient magic. She catches winds that other vessels can't feel, she's silent in flight, and her crew navigate by starlight and instinct. She's the most beautiful vessel in any sky and the hardest to detect.
vehicles.notes: The windrunner is your stealth vessel. She's nearly invisible to detection — magical or mundane — and she moves in absolute silence. Use her for infiltration, reconnaissance, and surprise attacks where the enemy doesn't know she's there until the arrows start falling.

vehicles.name: Bomber Dirigible
vehicles.desc: A rigid gasbag carrying a gondola packed with incendiary bombs, alchemical fire, and enough explosive to level a castle. She flies high, she drops her payload, and the world below burns. She's the strategic weapon of any aerial power wealthy enough to build one.
vehicles.notes: The bomber dirigible is your aerial siege weapon. She provides bombardment that ground-based defences can't answer without skyships of their own. Use her for strategic scenarios — she changes the nature of warfare, and defending against her requires entirely new thinking.

vehicles.name: Royal Flagship (Sky)
vehicles.desc: The monarch's vessel. Gilt railings, enchanted armour, a crew of the realm's finest sailors, and weapons that represent the peak of the kingdom's magical and mundane engineering. She's a symbol of power that happens to be the most dangerous vessel in the fleet.
vehicles.notes: The royal flagship is your campaign centrepiece. She carries the monarch, the admiral, or whatever leader the campaign revolves around. Protecting her is a sacred duty. Capturing her wins a war. She should appear rarely and always dramatically.
